div.head: ShilohIt "was Melville's bad luck that his 'Shiloh: A Requiem' would suggest, by contrast, the striking poem of Mr. Forceyth Willson's, of which a great part of the scene is laid on the battle-field of Shiloh, called 'The Old Sergeant" (Parker, II, 621). "The Old Sergeant" (1863) was republished in Edmund Clarence Stedman's An American Anthology, 1787-1900 (1900): https://www.bartleby.com/248/710.html.

A Requiem.
(April, 1862.)

lg.l: Over the field in clouded days,
Over the field where April rain
Solaced the parched ones stretched in pain
The church so lone, the log-built one,
That echoed to many a parting groan
Foemen at morn, but friends at eve—
Fame or country least their care:

l.note: This line was quoted at the beginning of the short story, Memento Mori, by Jonathan Nolan which his older brother Christopher used to write the screenplay for the 2000 move "Memento" (https://www.public.asu.edu/~srbeatty/366/MementoMori.pdf https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memento_%28film%29).

lg.l: While over them the swallows skim,

And all is hushed at ShilohThe sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet, until Shiloh come; and unto him shall the gathering of the people be (Genesis 49:10). NN Published Poems, pp. 637–38, notes that Melville had also referred to Hawthorne as "the literary Shiloh of America" in "Hawthorne and his Mosses" (NN Piazza Tales, 181). Hennig Cohen also cross-references HM's story "The Bell Tower": "A silence, as of the expectation of some Shiloh, pervaded the swarming plain" (NN Piazza Tales, 252)..
